sys_metadata_link.payload:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><record_update table="x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases"> <x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases action="INSERT_OR_UPDATE"> <common_name>Powdery mildew (Podosphaera tridactyla)</common_name> <description>How does Powdery mildew (Podosphaera tridactyla) occur? Erysiphe cichoracearum survives winter as spore-forming structures called cleistothecia on shoots, leaves, and bark. In spring, spores are released and spread by wind, water, or insects. They infect susceptible plants like plum trees, forming a white, powdery coating. The fungus grows, reproduces, and spreads the infection to other plants. It can also overwinter on plant debris or dormant buds.
</description> <family/> <host>prune,</host> <number>PLD0001035</number> <scientific_name>Podosphaera tridactyla</scientific_name> <solution>Chemical Control • Available fungicides for powdery mildew control include propiconazole (Orbit, Bumper), thiophanate methyl (Topsin-M), pyraclostrobin/boscalid (Pristine), myclobutanil (Rally), sulfur dust, wettable sulfur, and liquid lime sulfur.
• These fungicides have different modes of action and application rates. It is important to follow label instructions, including any restrictions on specific crops.
</solution> <sys_class_name>x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases</sys_class_name> <sys_created_by>admin</sys_created_by> <sys_created_on>2024-10-18 00:38:29</sys_created_on> <sys_id>3d0ccaf9971112109790fefce053af74</sys_id> <sys_mod_count>1</sys_mod_count> <sys_updated_by>admin</sys_updated_by> <sys_updated_on>2024-10-21 04:08:24</sys_updated_on> </x_snc_plant_mgmt_plant_diseases> </record_update>
